newsitem.title: FRANCE: SOCCER-BLANC SAYS MARSEILLE ARE NO BARCELONA.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-BLANC SAYS MARSEILLE ARE NO BARCELONA.

text.p: French international libero Laurent Blanc has no illusions about his new French club Marseille compared with the team he left to join them, Spanish giants Barcelona.
Despite celebrating his return to the French first division by scoring twice as Marseille beat Le Havre 3-1 on Saturday, Blanc said the former European champions could not be likened with Barcelona.
"If you ask me to compare Marseille to Barcelona, I'd rather not say anything. With all due respect to Marseille, Barcelona are a super team," the 31-year-old defender said.
But he feels Marseille could measure up better in the future. "Marseille is the only French club with the potential to become one day a great team like Barcelona," he said.
Blanc struggled last season to earn a regular place with Barcelona and returned to France with the two ambitions of leading Marseille back to the top and earning a place in France's World Cup squad.
Helping Marseille qualify for the European Cup competition "is more than a challenge, it is a must. This town won't accept failure," he said.
The former Auxerre player's first test as Marseille's new skipper was very promising.
A penalty in the 51st minute and a free kick five minutes later brought his goal tally in the first division to 70 as he saved his new team from a major setback.
Le Havre had opened the scoring in the 20th minute through Christophe Horlaville.
"Soccer remains a team sport. I'd rather talk about the reaction the team had after a poor start," said Blanc, who anchors the brand new defence built by new coach Rolland Courbis.
Xavier Gravelaine scored Marseille's third goal on the hour, allowing his team to take a very provisional second place in the league standings.
Marseille have no time to relax as they host Nantes on Friday in a key fixture.
It is a little too early for Blanc to make up his mind on whether he made the right choice.
"I rather liked this team. We still need to improve but it is only natural with eight new players," he said.
What most impressed the towering libero was the crowd, reduced to 20,000 while works for next summer's World Cup are under way.
"I was impressed by the noise they made in such a crippled stadium. When the works are completed, they will be a great bonus," Blanc added.
